skills.name: Identify where negative non-integers lie on a number line
Read a decimal on a scale where the required measurement is marked by a dash between two numbers

explanations.A: Not quite, I think you have thought the number line is between 0 and 10. Double check the number line again.
explanations.B: Nearly! I think you have miscounted. Double check the number line again.
explanations.C: Not quite, I think you have thought the number line is between 0 and 10. Double check the number line again. Your answer should be less than one.
explanations.D: Each mark on the number line represents 0.1. This is 4 marks over from zero, and so is the number 0.4

explanations.D: Nearly! I think you have miscounted. Double check the number line again.

explanations.A: Not quite, I think you thought the number lines were going up in 0.1s. The 1 has been divided into 5 parts, how much is each part?
explanations.B: Not quite, this arrow is not pointing to the middle of the number line. Try and see what each 'jump' is worth on the number line.
explanations.C: Each mark on the number line represents 0.2. This is 2 marks over from zero, and so is the number 0.4
explanations.D: Not quite, I think you have thought the number line is between 0 and 10. Double check the number line again. Your answer should be less than one.

explanations.A: Each mark on the number line represents 0.2. This is 3 marks over from zero, and so is the number 0.6.
explanations.B: Not quite, I think you thought the number lines were going up in 0.1s. The 1 has been divided into 5 parts, how much is each part?
explanations.C: Not quite, I think you have thought the number line is between 0 and 10. Double check the number line again. Your answer should be less than one.
explanations.D: Not quite, this arrow is not pointing to the middle of the number line. Try and see what each 'jump' is worth on the number line.

explanations.A: Not quite, I think you thought the number lines were going up in 0.1s. The 2 has been divided into 10 parts, how much is each part?
explanations.B: Not quite, I think you counted back 0.1 from the middle. The 2 has been divided into 10 parts, how much is each part?
explanations.C: Each mark on the number line represents 0.2. This is 4 marks over from zero, and so is the number 0.8.
explanations.D: Not quite, this arrow is not pointing to the middle of the number line. Try and see what each 'jump' is worth on the number line.

explanations.A: Each mark on the number line represents 0.2. This is 6 marks over from zero, and so is the number 1.2.
explanations.B: Not quite, this arrow is not pointing to the middle of the number line. Try and see what each 'jump' is worth on the number line.
explanations.C: Not quite, I think you thought the number lines were going up in 0.1s. The 2 has been divided into 10 parts, how much is each part?
explanations.D: Not quite, I think you counted forward 0.1 from the middle. The 2 has been divided into 10 parts, how much is each part?

explanations.A: Not quite, double check again what each 'jump' on the number line is worth.
explanations.B: Not quite, I think you thought the number lines were going up in 0.2s. The 2 has been divided into 8 parts, how much is each part?
explanations.C: Not quite, I think you thought the number lines were going up in 0.1s. The 2 has been divided into 8 parts, how much is each part?
explanations.D: Each jump on this number line is worth 2/8 = 0.25.The arrow is 1 jump back from 2, so it is 1.75

explanations.A: Not quite, I think you thought the number lines were going up in 0.1s. The 2 has been divided into 8 parts, how much is each part?
explanations.B: Each jump on this number line is worth 2/8 = 0.25.The arrow is 2 jumps back from 2, so it is 1.5
explanations.C: Not quite, double check again what each 'jump' on the number line is worth.
explanations.D: Not quite, double check again what each 'jump' on the number line is worth.

explanations.A: Nearly! This is to the left of zero, so must be a negative value.
explanations.B: Not quite, double check again what each 'jump' on the number line is worth. How can you go from 0 to 1 in 5 jumps?
explanations.C: Not quite, double check again what each 'jump' on the number line is worth. How can you go from 0 to 1 in 5 jumps?
explanations.D: Each jump on the number line is worth 0.2. This is 0.2 to the left of zero, and so is the number -0.2.

explanations.A: Not quite, double check again what each 'jump' on the number line is worth. How can you go from 0 to 1 in 4 jumps?
explanations.B: Each jump on the number line is worth 0.25. This is 0.25 to the left of zero, and so is the number -0.25.
explanations.C: Not quite, double check again what each 'jump' on the number line is worth. How can you go from 0 to 1 in 4 jumps?
explanations.D: Not quite, double check again what each 'jump' on the number line is worth. How can you go from 0 to 1 in 4 jumps?
